Michigan Historical Collections
Bentley Historical Library
University of Michigan
titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
William C. Weber Papers, 1858-1940

did.abstract: Detroit, Michigan businessman and civic leader. Business correspondence relating to Weber's activities as a dealer in timber lands, his role as a member of the Art Commission in the development of Detroit, Michigan's Cultural Center, his involvement in the construction of the Detroit-Windsor bridge and tunnel and his activities during World War I; and correspondence and class notes of his sons, Harry B. and Erwin W. Weber, while attending University of Michigan; also photographs, including family portraits, aerial views of Windsor, Ontario, and Detroit, photographs of the construction of the Detroit-Windsor Tunnel and Ambassador Bridge, and glass negatives of family vacations in Upper Michigan, Ontario, and Quebec; and maps of land and timber holdings

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Mrs. Harry D. Weber, William C. Weber's daughter-in-law (donor 4727) to the University of Michigan Library (donor 1278) in about 1969. It was thereafter transferred to the Michigan Historical Collections.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., William C. Weber Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: William C. Weber, a life-time resident of Detroit, was a land dealer in Michigan involved in lumber and minerals, as well as the owner of land in Detroit and the Border Cities (later Windsor, Ontario). Weber and his wife Emma (Behr) had two sons, Harry (born in 1888) and Erwin (born in 1892). Both sons went to the University of Michigan: Harry attended from 1907 to 1909 when he left to become his father's partner; Erwin attended from 1912 until graduation in 1916. Harry died in 1967. He and his wife Helen (who died in 1973) left no children. Erwin died in 1918 at the Great Lakes Naval Training Center from influenza.

In the first two decades of the century, Weber was involved in cultural events in Detroit, especially the development of the Cultural Center of the city of Detroit on Woodward Avenue. He and Joseph L. Hudson were the chief financial backers of the Art Commission's acquisition of the land on which the Main Library and Detroit Institute of Arts now stand. After Hudson's death in 1912, Weber became embroiled in a controversy over the design of the Cultural Center, failing, however, to sway other members of the commission to his position.

In the twenties and early thirties, Weber was interested in the construction of the Detroit-Windsor bridge and tunnel primarily because he held property in the Border Cities located strategically near the Canadian side of the bridge and near the industrial development of that area. During these years, he also was negotiating with the Ford Motor Company over land deals and the development of mineral lands in Michigan.

arrangement.p:
The William C. Weber papers are arranged in five series William C. Weber, Erwin C. Weber, and Harry B. Weber, Photographs and Maps. The William C. Weber series is further arranged in seven subseries:
William C. Weber papers
Correspondence, 1858-1940 -- Box 1-15
Letterbooks, 1878-1931 -- Box 16-18
Business and Property Records, ca. 1880-1934 -- Box 18
Papers Relating to the Detroit Cultural Center -- Box 19-20 and Outsize
Papers Relating to Detroit-Windsor Tunnel and Ambassador Bridge
Land and Timber Records, 1870s- ca. 1920? -- Box 20-23
Record of Land Purchases and Taxes, 1868-1928 - - Outsize
Miscellaneous, ca. 1870s-1914 -- Box 23
Erwin C. Weber papers, 1900-1918 -- Box 24
Harry B. Weber papers, 1906-1934 -- Box 25
Photographs -- Box 26-30
Maps (Outsize

scopecontent.p: The William C. Weber papers cover 28 linear feet (30 boxes), outsize folders, and 15 outsize volumes. Besides information on timber and mineral lands in Michigan, the important aspects of the Weber papers include information on the development of the Cultural Center of Detroit and Weber's very controversial role in it, items on the Detroit-Windsor bridge and tunnel and the development of the Border Cities, and the papers of his two sons, especially the letters they wrote as students at the University of Michigan and their class notes and examinations.
There is one foot of materials related to the Cultural Center (Box 19 and outsize folders) and another of the Detroit-Windsor Tunnel and Ambassador Bridge (Box 20 and outsize folders).
Architectural site plans and property maps of the Detroit Cultural Center are also found in the outsize unbound material.

The collection includes maps relating to Weber's his land holdings in northern Michigan and Windsor, Ontario, including maps of land survey, of timber estimates, and tax and title status for Michigan lands, maps of Windsor subdivisions, maps of coal mining region around Caryville, Tennessee and property maps of the Detroit Cultural Center.

scopecontent.p: The correspondence is organized chronologically and runs from 1858 to 1940 (Boxes 1-17). Business and personal correspondence is interfiled. Among the topics found in this file are Weber's land dealings, the Cultural Center, activities of family members and associates in Germany during and after World War I, and business correspondence of Harry Weber.

Papers relating to the Detroit Cultural Center

scopecontent.p: There is one foot of materials related to the Cultural Center (Box 19 and outsize folders) which documents Weber's role as a founder and trustee of the Cultural Center. the subseries includes files on the acquisition of the land for the site of the Center, the design competition, trustees minutes, a variety of financial and legal records, and outsize architectural site plans and property maps.

did.unittitle: Papers relating to Windsor property and the Detroit-Windsor tunnel and bridge

scopecontent.p: The Detroit-Windsor Tunnel and Ambassador Bridge papers (Box 20 and outsize folders) relate to Weber's property holdings in Windsor and development of the Windsor Tunnel and the Ambassador Bridge.

scopecontent.p: The Land and Timber Records subseries includes four feet (Boxes 20-23 and outsize folders) and 15 outsize volumes relate to Weber's land holdings. Chief among the land records are maps of Weber's holdings, compiled land purchase and tax records, and estimates of timber on Weber lands. The timber estimates are especially valuable as they contain detailed descriptions, and in many cases maps, of ground cover, environmental conditions, and cultural features on large tracts of land throughout northern Michigan.

scopecontent.p: The Erwin W. Weber series consists of letters, 1912-1918, to and from Weber primarily from his days as a student at the University of Michigan. Letters from his parents are filed in the William C. Weber Correspondence. The series also includes a number of course notebooks and examinations from classes taught by prominent UM faculty members, including Charles Horton Cooley, William Hobbs, Robert Mark Wenley, and Claude Van Tyne.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Harry B. Weber, William Weber's eldest son and business partner, also consists primarily of correspondence and course class notebooks for University of Michigan classes and notes on special lectures. The notebooks include courses taught by Earle. W. Dow, Frederick Taylor, Claude Van Tyne, Claude Hussey and Filibert Roth and special lectures by Henry Carter Adams, Robert Mark Wenly, Jacob Reighard and Edward Kraus. The Correspondence includes letters from Harry's student days as well as later professional life. Much of his business correspondence is filed in the William C. Weber Correspondence files.

scopecontent.p: Photographs are found in Boxes 26-30 and one outsize volume. Included are photos of the bridge and tunnel and Weber's Windsor properties, as well as a large file of glass negatives taken during family vacations in Upper Michigan, Ontario, and Quebec.

scopecontent.p: Maps are found in the outsize unbound material, as well as in the land records described above. The unbound maps relate primarily to Windsor and Essex County property, Michigan land, and to a lesser extent property in Tennessee and the West. Many published maps have been separated from the collection and cataloged individually in the Michigan Historical Collections map catalog. Some of these maps are annotated with information about Weber land holdings. The annotated maps can be found under the subject William C. Weber in the map catalog. Published maps remaining with the collection are generally duplicates of maps already in the map collection or portions that have been cut from larger maps. Most of the maps remaining with the collection are unpublished blueprints and sketch maps. Windsor and Essex County maps tend to be detailed plat maps showing urban subdivisions. Michigan maps are less detailed, but in some cases show railroads, roads, and settlements. The collection includes a number of detailed maps of the coal mining region around Careyville, Tennessee, and some less detailed maps of mining regions in the West.

odd.p: (shelved in basement map cases)
